elements.content: It still remains a great challenge to design and construct framework-structured weak ferromagnets with large canting angle which is an effective approach for high performance magnets. According to the strategy of antisymmetric interaction causing spin canting, we report the design of four cobalt compounds, which were tested by X-ray single crystal diffraction, TGA, PXRD, and magnetic measurement. Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that compound 1 has a 2D structure, complex 2 has a 3,4-connected 3D framework, and complex 3 exhibits a 3D net structure with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology and the solvent MeOH trapped in the 3D channels as guests. The magnetic property of 3 is spin canting just as designed, with T N about 4.0 K and large canting angle of 14.8°. Highly stable compound 3 sustains its framework in air for more than 12 months, in which the guest MeOH molecules can be replaced by water to form complex 4.

elements.content:
The stable cobalt-based framework-structured complex was synthesized which exhibits weak ferromagnetism with T N about 4.0 K and big canting angle of 14.8°.

Introduction

In recent years, molecule-based magnetic materials, with great potential applications for high-density information storage, quantum computing, and magnetic refrigeration, are the focus for physical and chemical researchers. In this field, framework-structured weak ferromagnets are a new research hot point, in which the framework structure is effective for long-range ordering of spins. The desired spontaneous magnetization will be gained as long as the canting angle (γ) is large enough. Up to the present, the canting angle in the framework structure system usually is small; accordingly, the relevant weak ferromagnets caused by spin canting do not have large spontaneous magnetization. Generally speaking, the phenomenon of spin canting is caused by two mechanisms, one by the existence of single-ion magnetic anisotropy and the other by antisymmetric interaction. The antisymmetric interaction is not convenient to control, while single-ion magnetic anisotropy is easy to realize by using anisotropic metal ions such as MnIII, CoII, and so on. From the structural point of view, the lack of inversion center is necessary for spin canting in local symmetry between the two coupling paramagnetic centers. Thus, if a ligand shows predicable asymmetric coordination modes, the phenomenon of spin canting may occur. Some bridging ligands, including dicyanamide, azido, and carboxylate, are potential candidates for constructing spin canting complexes. It is worth mentioning that bridging ligands with asymmetric coordination models are a good choice to obtain spin canting. A representative example has been reported by Bu and his co-workers with the use of 3,4-dicyano-1,2,5-thiadiazolea ligand. Enormous magnetic 3D frameworks with weak ferromagnetism have been explored, but the canting angle larger than 5° is very rare, with only one sample reported with angles exceeding 10°. Construction of framework-structured weak ferromagnet with large canting angle still remains a great challenge.

elements.content: Herein, on the basis of current research for a desired framework-structured weak ferromagnet, the CoII ion with single-ion magnetic anisotropy and pyrazine-2-carboxylate (Pzc) as bridging ligand were selected. By varying the coligand accommodated in the mother framework that is constructed by CoII and Pzc, we report here a case of magnetic modulation. Our results suggest that the obtained cobalt complex {[Co(Pzc)­(HCOO)]·MeOH} n (3) with spin-canting behavior presents a rare β-SnF2 net and exhibits weak ferromagnetism with T N about 4.0 K and a big canting angle of 14.8°. Our further experiments suggest that complex 3 can transform to complex 4, when the guest MeOH molecules are replaced by water molecules by means of single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation.

By varying the coligand accommodated in the mother framework that is constructed by CoII and Pzc, we report here a case of magnetic modulation. Our results suggest that the obtained cobalt complex {[Co(Pzc)(HCOO)]⋅MeOH} n  (3) with spin-canting behavior presents a rare β-SnF2 net and exhibits weak ferromagnetism with T N about 4.0 K and a big canting angle of 14.8°. elements.content: The chemical reagents used in these experiments are analytical grade and used without further purification. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of a sample was done by Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Thermal stability studies were taken using a NETSCHZ STA 449C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30–1000 °C range) at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The magnetic measurement was carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer by using crushed crystals of the sample. The magnetic field was 7 T. The diamagnetic susceptibility corrections were calculated from Pascal’s constants; an experimental correction for the sample holder was applied.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The chemical reagents used in these experiments are analytical grade and used without further purification. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of a sample was done by Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40 kV, 100 mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromator. Thermal stability studies were taken using a NETSCHZ STA 449C thermoanalyzer under N2 (30-1000 °C range) at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The magnetic measurement was carried out on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL SQUID magnetometer by using crushed crystals of the sample. The magnetic field was 7 T. The diamagnetic susceptibility corrections were calculated from Pascal's constants; an experimental correction for the sample holder was applied.

elements.content: A mixture of pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid (0.4 mmol), CoCl2·6H2O (2 mmol), and methanol (15 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb, heated to 140 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Block-shaped purple crystals of 1 were collected and washed sequentially by methanol.

Syntheses

[Co(Pzc)Cl(MeOH)] n  (1)

A mixture of pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid (0.4 mmol), CoCl2⋅6H2O (2 mmol), and methanol (15 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined bomb, heated to 140 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Block-shaped purple crystals of 1 were collected and washed sequentially by methanol.

After maintaining for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature, the complex 2 was collected and washed by methanol.

elements.content: With the complex 3 in air for a few months, the methanol molecules in the framework were replaced by water molecules, and the complex {[Co(Pzc)­(HCOO)]·MeOH} n (3) undergoes a single-crystal-to-single-crystal structural transition to the complex {[Co(Pzc)­(HCOO)]·2H2O} n (4).

{[Co(Pzc)(HCOO)]⋅2H2O} n  (4)

With the complex 3 in air for a few months, the methanol molecules in the framework were replaced by water molecules, and the complex {[Co(Pzc)(HCOO)]⋅MeOH} n  (3) undergoes a single-crystal-to-single-crystal structural transition to the complex {[Co(Pzc)(HCOO)]⋅2H2O} n  (4).

elements.content: Diffraction data collection for complexes 1–4 were performed at 293(2) K on a Rigaku SCX-mini diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) by ω scan mode. Rigaku CrystalClear program was applied to integrate the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2, with all non-hydrogen atoms refined with anisotropic thermal parameters (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). All of the metal atoms were located from the E-maps. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. All calculations were solved by using the SHELXTL crystallographic software. Crystallographic crystal data and refinement parameters are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths are listed in Table S1 of the .

The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2, with all non-hydrogen atoms refined with anisotropic thermal parameters (semiempirical absorption corrections were applied using SADABS program). All of the metal atoms were located from the E-maps. The hydrogen atoms of the ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. All calculations were solved by using the SHELXTL crystallographic software. Crystallographic crystal data and refinement parameters are summarized in Table . During the experiments, three complexes were obtained step by step. The complex [Co(Pzc)Cl­(MeOH)] n (1) containing one coordinated methanol molecule was synthesized by mixing pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid and CoCl2·6H2O in methanol solvent (complex 1 is unstable). With an adjustment to the molar ratio of the reactants, 3D formwork {[Co3(Pzc)4­Cl2]·2H2O} n (2) supported by guest water molecules was produced (complex 2 is unstable in humid air). The ratio of the reactants is very important for getting different crystals of 1 and 2, despite those being synthesized under similar conditions. Also, pure phase complex 2 (checked by PXRD, Figure S1) could be obtained with ligand–metal ratio of 2:5. The complex {[Co(Pzc)­(HCOO)]·MeOH} n (3) was gained by mixing the pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid and Co(HCO2)2·4H2O in the methanol solvent (complex 3 is stable). In this work, we aimed to get the magnetic materials; however, we found complex 1 was unstable and out of the testing requirement of other measurement. We speculate that the instability of complex 1 is caused by the methanol molecule participating in the coordination, and the instability of 2 is due to the coordination of the chloride anions which are easy to decoordinate in humid condition. Aimed at solving these problems, we change the reactants and introduced the bridging molecules (formate anions) which can make the molecule framework stable. Finally, the stable complex 3 was gained, and structural analysis shows that formate anions participate in the coordination and bridge the metal ions forming a 3D net with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology. Thermal stability studies indicate complex 3 has high thermal stability and decomposes above 300 °C ( Figure S2a). Its phase purity was confirmed by PXRD ( Figure S2b), and the magnetic measurement reveals that complex 3 exhibits weak ferromagnetic with T N about 4.0 K and big canting angle of 14.8°.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis, Structure, and Description of Complexes 1-3 

During the experiments, three complexes were obtained step by step. The complex [Co(Pzc)Cl(MeOH)] n  (1) containing one coordinated methanol molecule was synthesized by mixing pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid and CoCl2⋅6H2O in methanol solvent (complex 1 is unstable). With an adjustment to the molar ratio of the reactants, 3D formwork {[Co3(Pzc)4Cl2]⋅2H2O} n  (2) supported by guest water molecules was produced (complex 2 is unstable in humid air). The ratio of the reactants is very important for getting different crystals of 1 and 2, despite those being synthesized under similar conditions. Also, pure phase complex 2 (checked by PXRD,  Figure S1) could be obtained with ligand-metal ratio of 2:5. The complex {[Co(Pzc)(HCOO)]⋅MeOH} n  (3) was gained by mixing the pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid and Co(HCO2)2⋅4H2O in the methanol solvent (complex 3 is stable). In this work, we aimed to get the magnetic materials; however, we found complex 1 was unstable and out of the testing requirement of other measurement. We speculate that the instability of complex 1 is caused by the methanol molecule participating in the coordination, and the instability of 2 is due to the coordination of the chloride anions which are easy to decoordinate in humid condition. Aimed at solving these problems, we change the reactants and introduced the bridging molecules (formate anions) which can make the molecule framework stable. Finally, the stable complex 3 was gained, and structural analysis shows that formate anions participate in the coordination and bridge the metal ions forming a 3D net with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology. Thermal stability studies indicate complex 3 has high thermal stability and decomposes above 300 °C ( Figure S2a). Its phase purity was confirmed by PXRD ( Figure S2b), and the magnetic measurement reveals that complex 3 exhibits weak ferromagnetic with T N about 4.0 K and big canting angle of 14.8°.

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21 /n with an asymmetric unit consisting of one crystallographically independent CoII center, one deprotonated ligand Pzc anion, one chlorine anion, and one coordinated methanol molecule. The CoII ion is coordinated by one inorganic chloride atom, one methanol oxygen atom, two oxygen atoms, and two nitrogen atoms from three Pzc anions forming a distorted octahedral geometry with normal bond lengths ( Table S1). Each Pzc anion adopts a μ3 coordination mode to bridge three CoII ions, while the chlorine atom and the methanol molecule both take the axis positions to coordinate to the CoII ion [bond lengths: Co1–Cl2 = 2.3759 (10) Å, Co1–O1 = 2.1627 (18) Å] (Figure a). In this way, every CoII is connecting to three Pzc anions, and every Pzc anion is linking three metal ions, to form a 2D layer structure (Figure b).

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4/ncc, and the asymmetric unit of 2 contains one and a half crystallographic CoII ions, two Pzc anions, one chlorine anion, and two solvated water molecules. Co1 is coordinated by two chloride anions and four nitrogen atoms from four Pzc anions. Co2 is coordinated by four Pzc anions, in which two Pzc anions take chelating mode. The Pzc anion adopts a μ3 coordination mode to bridge Co1, Co2, and Co2G ions. The Pzc anion chelates to Co2 ion via 1-position N1 atom and a carboxylate O1 atom, and coordinates to Co1 and Co2G in a monodentate fashion via the 4-position N2 atom and the other carboxylate O2 atom of the syn–anti carboxylate, respectively (Figure a). It is worth noticing that an elongated octahedral cage was formed by four Co2 ions, two Co1 ions, and four Pzc anions ( Figure S3a), and linked by Co1 ions generating a 1D chain ( Figure S3b). The 1D chains share Co2 ions forming a 3D net structure with water molecules filled in the channels of the cages (Figure b). Also, the whole framework could be viewed as 3,4-connected topology net ( Figure S3c).

elements.content: Complex 3 has a 3D structure with the space group of P212121. In the crystallographic asymmetric unit, there exists one crystallographically independent CoII ion, one Pzc anion, one formate anion, and one solvated methanol molecule (Figure a). Each CoII lies in a general position with a distorted octahedral geometry constructed by two nitrogen atoms, two oxygen atoms of three Pzc anions, and two oxygen atoms of two formate anions. The Pzc taking μ3 mode coordinates to two CoII ions in monodentate model by one carboxylate oxygen and 4-position nitrogen, and to the third CoII ion in a chelating fashion via the other carboxylate oxygen and 1-position nitrogen (Figure b). The Pzc cobalt network exhibits a (10, 3)-a net ( Figure S4a), which is different from the (10,3)-d net in {[Ni(Pzc)­Cl(H2O)]·MeOH} n . In b direction, the formate anions take anti–anti bridging mode linking two CoII ions, which strengthens the net (Figures S4b and S5). From the point of view of topology, in the 3D structure, the Pzc linked three CoII ions could be viewed as 3-connected nodes, while the CoII ion was defined as 5-connected nodes due to CoII ions bridged by the formate anions which are not linked by the Pzc directly. Thus, the whole network exhibits a rare 3, 5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology with Schläfli symbol {52·6}{53·63·73·8} ( Figure S4b).

elements.content: Herein, we need to further summarize the process of obtaining stable framework. As is shown in Figure , the design and synthesis of the stable framework is realized step-by-step. In 1, as terminal groups, the methanol molecules coordinate to CoII centers; thus, further extension of the 2D network is impossible. When exposed to the air, complex 1 collapses quickly at room temperature, and loses its crystalline state in about 72 h (Figure c). Such instability may be caused by the terminal coordination groups of methanol molecules. In the further exploration of the stable structures, compound 2 was obtained. In 2, by adjusting the molar ratio of initial reactants, the terminal methanol molecules in 1 are driven off from the structure, and the Cl atoms are introduced to coordinate to CoII centers. Subsequently, compound 2 extends itself into 3D 3,4-connected framework supported by guest water molecules. It is found that compound 2 exhibits higher stability as compared with 1. It loses its crystalline state gradually in 10 days. As is shown in Figure c, the stability of this structure has been improved greatly. With further exploration, with the hope of introducing bridging ligands to further strengthen the whole structure, Co(HCO2)2·4H2O was used instead of CoCl2·6H2O. As expected, the formate anions in 3 participate in the construction of the whole 3D framework. Stable an experiment shows that complex 3 is stable and could remain crystalline for more than 12 months. From the structural design and stability of complexes 1–3, we can see that the auxiliary ligand-directed strategy is an effective method for gaining stable magnetic frameworks. Moreover, due to the host–guest structural characteristics of the frameworks, it is possible to design and construct other multifunctional magnetic materials by changing the guest molecules.

elements.content: Variable-temperature susceptibilities on pure powder samples of 2 were collected under an external field of 1 kOe. χm versus T and χm T versus T plots were shown in Figure S6 and Figure . The χm T product at 300 K is 8.44 cm3 K mol–1 and is a typical value of the three high spin CoII ions with strong spin–orbit coupling in octahedral geometry. Also, the χm T curve decreases smoothly with cooling and gives a value of 4.78 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities above 30 K following the Curie–Weiss law ( Figure S7) defined the constant of Θ = −10.31 K. The field-dependent magnetizations follow the Brillouin function (S = 1/2, g = 4.3) and reach saturation at 7 T. In the structure, the syn–anti carboxylate bridged Co2 ions give a 4,4 net, and then the Co2 ions of the 4,4 nets were linked with the Co1 ions by pyrazine ring to construct a 3D framework of complex 2. It is worth noticing that a Weiss constant −10.31 K of 2 is larger than the value −20 K of one isolated high-spin CoII ion with the contribution of spin–orbit coupling, so the ferromagnetic coupling contributions should be expected in 2. A ferrimagnetic state would be present if the magnetic interactions conducted by the carboxylate groups are ferromagnetic and those by the pyrazine ring are antiferromagnetic. That is inconsistent with the tendency of χm T and field dependent magnetization at 2 K. Thus, the magnetic interactions should be antiferromagnetically conducted by syn,syn carboxylate, and ferromagnetic by pyrazine ring.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature susceptibilities on pure powder samples of 2 were collected under an external field of 1 kOe. χm versus T and χm T versus T plots were shown in  Figure S6 and Figure . The χm T product at 300 K is 8.44 cm3 K mol-1 and is a typical value of the three high spin CoII ions with strong spin-orbit coupling in octahedral geometry. Also, the χm T curve decreases smoothly with cooling and gives a value of 4.78 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities above 30 K following the Curie-Weiss law ( Figure S7) defined the constant of Θ = -10.31 K. The field-dependent magnetizations follow the Brillouin function (S = 1/2, g = 4.3) and reach saturation at 7 T. In the structure, the syn-anti carboxylate bridged Co2 ions give a 4,4 net, and then the Co2 ions of the 4,4 nets were linked with the Co1 ions by pyrazine ring to construct a 3D framework of complex 2. It is worth noticing that a Weiss constant -10.31 K of 2 is larger than the value -20 K of one isolated high-spin CoII ion with the contribution of spin-orbit coupling, so the ferromagnetic coupling contributions should be expected in 2. A ferrimagnetic state would be present if the magnetic interactions conducted by the carboxylate groups are ferromagnetic and those by the pyrazine ring are antiferromagnetic. That is inconsistent with the tendency of χm T and field dependent magnetization at 2 K. Thus, the magnetic interactions should be antiferromagnetically conducted by syn,syn carboxylate, and ferromagnetic by pyrazine ring.

elements.content: Variable-temperature susceptibilities of complex 3 were investigated on powder samples in temperature range of 2–300 K under an applied field of 2 kOe. As shown in Figure S8 and Figure , the χm versus T plots have a increase below 20 K, and the χm T plots have a value of 3.40 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K, which is a typical value of one CoII ion located in an octahedral environment. Above 40 K the susceptibility data could be fitted by the Curie–Weiss law and give a Weiss constant Θ = −21.20 K ( Figure S9). The initial decrease of χm T product on cooling and the negative value of Weiss constant should be due to the antiferromagnetic interactions and single ion effect of the octahedral CoII ions. Each CoII ion in 3 was connected to eight neighbors through two anti–anti formate anions and three Pzc ligands. Antiferromagnetic interactions should be conducted by the syn–syn carboxylate and formate anions in anti–anti fashion. Weak ferro- or antiferromagnetic magnetic interactions were transferred through the pyrazine rings for long exchange distances. The trend of the χm T plots with a minimum is typical behavior of weak ferromagnets. The presence of spontaneous magnetization is suggested by the sharp peak at 4 K. Also, the long-range order was further confirmed by the zero-field cooled (ZFC) and field cooled (FC) magnetization collected at 20 Oe (Figure inset). The ZFC and FC magnetization curves diverge below 4.0 K, confirmed the presence of spontaneous magnetization. In order to further comprehend the characteristic at low temperature, ac susceptibilities were measured in different ac frequencies (10–1000 Hz) with oscillating field of 3.5 Oe. Both the in- and out-of-phase signals are strong ( Figure S10). The in-phase signals χm′ show peaks at 4.2 K, and the peaks of χm″ are unsymmetrical and have little frequency dependence. That may be attributed to the moving of the domain walls and/or the orbital liquid behavior, which has also been found in recently reported canting systems.

elements.content: The canted antiferromagnetic order was also confirmed by the magnetization M(H) at low temperature 2 K (inset of Figure ). At very low field, the magnetization increases quickly to 0.6 Nβ, and then increases linearly to 1.44 Nβ at 50 kOe. The value of 1.44 Nβ is much less than the value of 2.15 Nβ for a CoII ion at 2 K (S = 1/2, g = 4.3), which confirms the antiferromagnetic interaction between the metal ions in 3. The intercept of the linear part of the magnetization curve in high field gives a value of 0.57 Nβ. That value could be taken as the compensating magnetization (M r ) arising from the canted antiferromagnetic spins. Thus, a canting angle of 14.8° can be estimated roughly, on the basis of the equation θ = tan–1(M r/M s).

elements.content: As is discussed above, complex 3 is a 3D host–guest stable framework. To achieve the functional design of magnetic materials, the framework requires tunable host–guest characteristics. In our following experiments, we further confirmed that the solvent methanol molecules in complex 3 could be replaced by water molecules, and then complex 4 was gained. The coordination condition of CoII ions and linkage modes of the Pzc in 4 are shown in Figure . The 3D framework structure of 4 is similar to that of 3 but with free water molecules filled in the channels. It is worth pointing out that such crystal-to-crystal transformation opens the way to synthesize a large family of multifunctional magnetic materials. Here we should further point out that according to the diverse extendable ligands (such as pyridine-carboxylate, 4-carboxyphenoxyacetic acid, pyrimidine-carboxylate, imidazole-carboxylate, etc.) and anisotropic metal ions (CoII, FeII, NiII, etc.), it could be expected that such a spin canting strategy would expand the functional design of magnetic materials, and relevant work has been undertaken.

Conclusions

A formate anion auxiliary-coordination strategy for designing and fabricating stable magnetic framework has been developed by using pyrazine-2-carboxylate and CoII ions. Complex 3 has a 3D net structure with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology, and the solvent MeOH molecules are filled in the 3D channel as guests. The magnetic properties of 3 include spin canting just as designed with T N about 4.0 K and a large canting angle of 14.8°. Moreover, the guest MeOH molecules in 3 can be replaced by water molecules to form new crystal materials 4. This work may further provide reference in the field of designing magnetic materials and guidance in related fields.

cln_elements.content:
Herein, on the basis of current research for a desired framework-structured weak ferromagnet, the CoII ion with single-ion magnetic anisotropy and pyrazine-2-carboxylate (Pzc) as bridging ligand were selected. By varying the coligand accommodated in the mother framework that is constructed by CoII and Pzc, we report here a case of magnetic modulation. Our results suggest that the obtained cobalt complex {[Co(Pzc)­(HCOO)]·MeOH} n (3) with spin-canting behavior presents a rare β-SnF2 net and exhibits weak ferromagnetism with T N about 4.0 K and a big canting angle of 14.8°. Our further experiments suggest that complex 3 can transform to complex 4, when the guest MeOH molecules are replaced by water molecules by means of single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis, Structure, and Description of Complexes <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold>

During the experiments, three complexes were obtained step by step. The complex [Co(Pzc)Cl­(MeOH)] n (1) containing one coordinated methanol molecule was synthesized by mixing pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid and CoCl2·6H2O in methanol solvent (complex 1 is unstable). With an adjustment to the molar ratio of the reactants, 3D formwork {[Co3(Pzc)4­Cl2]·2H2O} n (2) supported by guest water molecules was produced (complex 2 is unstable in humid air). The ratio of the reactants is very important for getting different crystals of 1 and 2, despite those being synthesized under similar conditions. Also, pure phase complex 2 (checked by PXRD, Figure S1) could be obtained with ligand–metal ratio of 2:5. The complex {[Co(Pzc)­(HCOO)]·MeOH} n (3) was gained by mixing the pyrazine-2-carboxylate acid and Co(HCO2)2·4H2O in the methanol solvent (complex 3 is stable). In this work, we aimed to get the magnetic materials; however, we found complex 1 was unstable and out of the testing requirement of other measurement. We speculate that the instability of complex 1 is caused by the methanol molecule participating in the coordination, and the instability of 2 is due to the coordination of the chloride anions which are easy to decoordinate in humid condition. Aimed at solving these problems, we change the reactants and introduced the bridging molecules (formate anions) which can make the molecule framework stable. Finally, the stable complex 3 was gained, and structural analysis shows that formate anions participate in the coordination and bridge the metal ions forming a 3D net with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology. Thermal stability studies indicate complex 3 has high thermal stability and decomposes above 300 °C ( Figure S2a). Its phase purity was confirmed by PXRD ( Figure S2b), and the magnetic measurement reveals that complex 3 exhibits weak ferromagnetic with T N about 4.0 K and big canting angle of 14.8°.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature susceptibilities on pure powder samples of 2 were collected under an external field of 1 kOe. χm versus T and χm T versus T plots were shown in Figure S6 and Figure . The χm T product at 300 K is 8.44 cm3 K mol–1 and is a typical value of the three high spin CoII ions with strong spin–orbit coupling in octahedral geometry. Also, the χm T curve decreases smoothly with cooling and gives a value of 4.78 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities above 30 K following the Curie–Weiss law ( Figure S7) defined the constant of Θ = −10.31 K. The field-dependent magnetizations follow the Brillouin function (S = 1/2, g = 4.3) and reach saturation at 7 T. In the structure, the syn–anti carboxylate bridged Co2 ions give a 4,4 net, and then the Co2 ions of the 4,4 nets were linked with the Co1 ions by pyrazine ring to construct a 3D framework of complex 2. It is worth noticing that a Weiss constant −10.31 K of 2 is larger than the value −20 K of one isolated high-spin CoII ion with the contribution of spin–orbit coupling, so the ferromagnetic coupling contributions should be expected in 2. A ferrimagnetic state would be present if the magnetic interactions conducted by the carboxylate groups are ferromagnetic and those by the pyrazine ring are antiferromagnetic. That is inconsistent with the tendency of χm T and field dependent magnetization at 2 K. Thus, the magnetic interactions should be antiferromagnetically conducted by syn,syn carboxylate, and ferromagnetic by pyrazine ring.

Conclusions

A formate anion auxiliary-coordination strategy for designing and fabricating stable magnetic framework has been developed by using pyrazine-2-carboxylate and CoII ions. Complex 3 has a 3D net structure with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology, and the solvent MeOH molecules are filled in the 3D channel as guests. The magnetic properties of 3 include spin canting just as designed with T N about 4.0 K and a large canting angle of 14.8°. Moreover, the guest MeOH molecules in 3 can be replaced by water molecules to form new crystal materials 4. This work may further provide reference in the field of designing magnetic materials and guidance in related fields.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature susceptibilities on pure powder samples of 2 were collected under an external field of 1 kOe. χm versus T and χm T versus T plots were shown in  Figure S6 and Figure . The χm T product at 300 K is 8.44 cm3 K mol-1 and is a typical value of the three high spin CoII ions with strong spin-orbit coupling in octahedral geometry. Also, the χm T curve decreases smoothly with cooling and gives a value of 4.78 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. The susceptibilities above 30 K following the Curie-Weiss law ( Figure S7) defined the constant of Θ = -10.31 K. The field-dependent magnetizations follow the Brillouin function (S = 1/2, g = 4.3) and reach saturation at 7 T. In the structure, the syn-anti carboxylate bridged Co2 ions give a 4,4 net, and then the Co2 ions of the 4,4 nets were linked with the Co1 ions by pyrazine ring to construct a 3D framework of complex 2. It is worth noticing that a Weiss constant -10.31 K of 2 is larger than the value -20 K of one isolated high-spin CoII ion with the contribution of spin-orbit coupling, so the ferromagnetic coupling contributions should be expected in 2. A ferrimagnetic state would be present if the magnetic interactions conducted by the carboxylate groups are ferromagnetic and those by the pyrazine ring are antiferromagnetic. That is inconsistent with the tendency of χm T and field dependent magnetization at 2 K. Thus, the magnetic interactions should be antiferromagnetically conducted by syn,syn carboxylate, and ferromagnetic by pyrazine ring. 

Conclusions

A formate anion auxiliary-coordination strategy for designing and fabricating stable magnetic framework has been developed by using pyrazine-2-carboxylate and CoII ions. Complex 3 has a 3D net structure with rare 3,5-connected 2-nodal β-SnF2 topology, and the solvent MeOH molecules are filled in the 3D channel as guests. The magnetic properties of 3 include spin canting just as designed with T N about 4.0 K and a large canting angle of 14.8°. Moreover, the guest MeOH molecules in 3 can be replaced by water molecules to form new crystal materials 4. This work may further provide reference in the field of designing magnetic materials and guidance in related fields.
